bestBHT.bht: Jesus confidently stood before the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council and declared Himself as the Messiah and the Son of the Blessed One. This proclamation carried great significance, surpassing His earlier confession before Pilate. By using the phrase From this time, Jesus denoted the shift and indicated that He would be glorified and eventually revealed in His Second Coming. Mark's resolute statement complements Matthew's account, affirming Jesus's claims and Caiaphas's conduct without any room for doubt.

Henry Alford: 62.] The “henceforth” of Matthew, and “from this time” of Luke are here omitted.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: In this view of it, the apostle is referring not to what our Lord confessed before Pilate—which, though noble, was not of such primary importance—but to that sublime confession which, under Pilate's administration, He witnessed before the only competent tribunal on such occasions, the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council of God's chosen nation, that He was THE MESSIAH, and THE SON OF THE BLESSED ONE in the former word owning His Supreme Official, in the latter His Supreme Personal, Dignity.

The word rendered 'hereafter' means, not 'at some future time' (as to-day 'hereafter' commonly does), but what the English word originally signified, 'after here,' 'after now,' or 'from this time.' Accordingly, in Luke 22:69, the words used mean 'from now.'

Though the reference we have given it to the day of His glorious Second Appearing is too obvious to admit of doubt, He would, by using the expression, 'From this time,' convey the important thought which He had before expressed, immediately after the traitor left the supper table to do his dark work, 'Now is the Son of man glorified' (Luke 22:69).
Philip Schaff: Any allusion to the significant name of God: ‘I Am’ (Exodus 3:14), is very improbable.
‘From henceforth’ is omitted here. See notes on Matthew 26:64.
Archibald T. Robertson: Mark's statement is definite beyond controversy.
See on Matthew 26:64-68 for the claims of Jesus and the conduct of Caiaphas.
John Gill: ...and ye shall see the son of man sitting on the right hand of power...
...and coming in the clouds of heaven...

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus, standing before the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council, confessed before them that He was the Messiah and the Son of the Blessed One. This confession, made in the presence of His adversaries and judges, held primary importance. By saying From this time, Jesus indicated His awareness that from that moment onward, He would be glorified and ultimately revealed in His Second Coming. This definitive statement by Mark reinforces the claims of Jesus and the conduct of Caiaphas, as described in Matthew's account. It leaves no room for doubt or uncertainty.

Jesus, in the presence of the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council, declared Himself as the Messiah and the Son of the Blessed One. This confession had great significance, surpassing His noble confession before Pilate. By stating From this time, Jesus emphasized His imminent glorification and His ultimate return, as previously mentioned after the traitor's departure. Mark's resolute statement approves Matthew's account and substantiates Jesus's claims and Caiaphas's conduct. It leaves no room for doubt, highlighting the criticality of this monumental moment.

Jesus confidently declared before the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council that He was the Messiah and the Son of the Blessed One. This confession, made in the presence of His adversaries and judges, held primary importance. By saying From this time, Jesus indicated His awareness that from that moment onward, He would be glorified and ultimately revealed in His Second Coming. This definitive statement by Mark reinforces the claims of Jesus and the conduct of Caiaphas, as described in Matthew's account.

Jesus confidently stood before the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council and declared Himself as the Messiah and the Son of the Blessed One. This proclamation carried great significance, surpassing His earlier confession before Pilate. By using the phrase From this time, Jesus denoted the shift and indicated that He would be glorified and eventually revealed in His Second Coming. Mark's resolute statement complements Matthew's account, affirming Jesus's claims and Caiaphas's conduct without any room for doubt.

Jesus boldly asserted His identity before the Supreme Ecclesiastical Council, proclaiming Himself as the Messiah and the Son of the Blessed One. This confession carried immense significance, surpassing His noble declaration before Pilate. By uttering the words From this time, Jesus demonstrated His awareness that He would be glorified and ultimately revealed in His Second Coming. Mark's assertive statement confirms and reinforces the claims of Jesus and the conduct of Caiaphas, aligning with the account presented in Matthew. Doubt or uncertainty finds no place within this resolute assertion.
